article:
A 'detergent' is a surfactant or a mixture of surfactants with "cleaning
properties in dilute solutions." These substances are usually
alkylbenzenesulfonates, a family of compounds that are similar to soap but are
more soluble in hard water, because the polar sulfonate (of detergents) is less
likely than the polar carboxyl (of soap) to bind to calcium and other ions found
in hard water. In most household contexts, the term detergent by itself refers
specifically to [[laundry detergent]] or [[Dishwashing liquid|dish detergent]],
as opposed to hand soap or other types of cleaning agents. Detergents are
commonly available as powders or concentrated solutions. Detergents, like soaps,
work because they are amphiphilic: partly hydrophilic (polar) and partly
hydrophobic (non-polar). Their dual nature facilitates the mixture of
hydrophobic compounds (like oil and grease) with water. Because air is not
hydrophilic, detergents are also foaming agents to varying degrees.
